Ruby Hash vs. JavaScript Objects

12.11.2014

Week 7 brought the switching of gears! After getting my feet wet with Ruby, we started working with JavaScript today. I found my head awash with parentheses and semicolons this week. In an effort to clarify some of the concepts we went over and the differences between the two languages, here is a post on Ruby hashes and JavaScript objects.

To refresh, a Ruby hash is a way to store data, with emphasis on order. Objects are stored as key, value pairs, as so:

Javascript doesn't have a hash collection. Fear not, though, for there is an alternative. Reader, meet object literals:

It doesn't look all that different, right? Object literals are a list of property names (always variables) with associated values.

Ruby keys = JavaScript object properties

To access information in the object literal, refer to the object and property like this:

//=> "pepperoni"

To access information in a Ruby hash:


=> "pepperoni"

JavaScript: to change the pizza property from "pepperoni" to "mushroom" do this:

Ruby:

If a property hasn't been added yet in JavaScript, you will get: food.dessert;
//=> undefined

JavaScript: to add an additional property to food:

Ruby:
